0: Richard Doud: Would you think that the best approach would be to mount
exhibits along the lines of Bitter Years, or ...
16: Theodor Jung: Well, one of the most important things, and I'm still
wondering why it hasn't been done, is to bring out a good, big book of
the FSA photographs, say three or four hundred photographs from there.
34: Richard Doud: One of the problems I think with an exhibit like The Bitter
Years is that, as far as exploiting the file, is that to me it gives
sort of a false impression of what the FSA file really is. Bitter Years
really is a pretty hard show-
67: Richard Doud: The file is very, very...
68: Theodor Jung: It's much more, very diversified than this small selection
73: Richard Doud: Yes, and I think that-
74: Theodor Jung: That's right. It does give a false picture.
78: Richard Doud: I don't know whether, along with this show, there's any
sort of implication that this is only part of the 30s or not. But I'm
afraid that people see the show feel that this was all there was to be
said by government photographers and I personally know that there is
104: Theodor Jung: Oh, yeah, that's right.
105: Richard Doud:... and much good news and much hope in the file.
110: Theodor Jung: Mainly missing, I think, was the element of humor, and there
was an awful lot of, I think really good funny pictures in the file, at
least I remember quite a few. That's been left out entirely. And, of
course, the wonderful scenic shots of America, too. Those were used, of
course, in other publications, particularly, you know, the various state
handbooks. Awful lot of our pictures got into those-
138: Theodor Jung: Yeah. That's right. Yeah. I think that would be a good thing
to have an exhibit which was more comprehensive and show more facets of
what the files contained. And of course a book could do that also.
160: Richard Doud: The problem... One of the problems...
163: Theodor Jung: Another, I guess, lack in [inaudible 00:02:47] is the fact
that no pictures were probably taken of prosperous farms or farmers,
175: Theodor Jung: Was there a little of that? I don't recollect myself.
178: Richard Doud: I think that probably you left too soon. Later on, this was a
definite point that was made and was reflected later in the definite
change of direction in the file that the accent in the earlier years had
been really on poverty and deprivation. It was felt that if you're
going out of your way to take a picture of the face of America, let's
do the whole job and let's show that all farmers aren't living in
tumble-down shacks, and I think later on there was a good deal of this
showing more normal conditions. They never reached the point, of course,
where they dealt to any great extent with the wealthy, but they did show
that America had something other than depressed farmers. This was an
important thing, and I suppose some of these stories are apocryphal
about Germans wanting pictures for the file hoping to show that America
was decadent and deteriorating and they were able to bring out pictures
269: Theodor Jung: The Russians I think would have probably been also good
275: Richard Doud: I'm sure they would have. Yeah. But I think this is one of
the problems now with doing something with the file is that really the
impression is that it's an especially morbid group of pictures.
294: Richard Doud: A pretty morbid group of pictures and an effort must be made
to show the versatility. I think it's important too, although there is
309: Theodor Jung: Now, isn't there something of the creative rural life? I
remember I took a series of pictures, I guess this was for agriculture,
not FSA, of rural handicraft that were very beautiful showing the
different things that were done in the highlands. Did any of those, that
type of thing get into the FSA files? If it didn't, they certainly
missed an important aspect of rural life.
336: Richard Doud: Well, different things were done along the lines of following
the various trades. In other words, in the field of production of goods
from raw materials through the various stages to finished product types
and this sort of thing, where it wasn't-
363: Theodor Jung: You mean like canned goods?
365: Richard Doud: Oh, like, yeah. Or from wheat to bread and from ore to...
371: Richard Doud:...to metal and this sort of thing. There was a
certain amount of that going on.
381: Theodor Jung: Because I was thinking more in terms of the individual
with the little crate, [inaudible 00:06:31] fellow who did whittling
394: Theodor Jung:... sculpture or weaving and hook rugs. Quite a lot of nice
things were done in the eastern highlands of this kind. They compare
well with some of the nice handicrafts.
412: Richard Doud: I don't know how much they-
413: Theodor Jung: I think that might have been missed.
418: Richard Doud: I'm sure a lot was missed. We must admit a lot was captured.
Well, can you think of anything else that we should say?
428: Theodor Jung: Well let's see what the... Did we... Couple of files had
[inaudible 00:07:18] today. Might as well turn it off for a second.
442: Richard Doud: This suggestion you were making about-
445: Theodor Jung: It seems to me that somewhere in this country there should be
a museum that is dedicated to the social and economic life of
contemporary America, which would consist not only of photographs, which
would be a very important part of the exhibit, but possibly also models,
dioramas, pictorial statistical charts and, of course, captions to show
what America is like today. Its composition racially, for example, by
industry, what percentage of people are in various industries, where
they come from, groupings within our, shall we say, income groups by
various levels, and then examine how the various income levels live,
what their income is, how they spend it, what they do with their time on
a rather, I think, a rather large and comprehensive scale. I don't
think this is being done anywhere in the United States today.
536: Richard Doud: You feel this should be a government job or should it be the
job of a private foundation? It might make a difference, you know, how
544: Theodor Jung: I presume it would. Yeah, I think it probably would be best
to have something like the Smithsonian. This would be sort of
semi-governmental, or is the Smithsonian completely independent?
562: Richard Doud: As I understand it, the Smithsonian is nonpolitical in any
567: Theodor Jung: Yeah. Well, it certainly should be nonpolitical, but-
570: Theodor Jung:... does it get any money from the government, or is it on a
private, or do you know? At any rate, it ought to be free of any sort of
578: Richard Doud: The Smithsonian is a strange and devious institution, and I
don't think they're quite sure what their operation is, and I feel
sure that no outsider has any idea how the Smithsonian operates. It's
sort of a multipartite operation of some sort, which is good I guess, in
a way, that it is outside the political influence because even
politicians don't understand how it's run. I don't know what the association is with the government.
620: Theodor Jung: The idea I actually got from, in Vienna there is such a
museum. It's called Gesellschafts- und Wirtschaftsmuseum, which means museum of society
633: Richard Doud: Is it a government museum?
635: Theodor Jung: It is, I think, run officially by the city of Vienna.
639: Theodor Jung: It's sponsored by government, yes.
643: Richard Doud: But dealing with Austria, or Austrian-
645: Theodor Jung: Austria as a whole, yeah. That's right. Yeah.
649: Theodor Jung: As a sort of a prototype. Of course, we could do it on a much
larger scale than they could with our resources, if we had the interest.
I would say that Washington would probably be the best place for it
because this is the one sort of hub of America. Either there, or
possibly New York. Somewhere where anybody can come and see it and
glance what a rich, varied life is in America even at the present time.
Perhaps also with leading up to it, too, with maybe historical plus
contemporary, which would show the development and growth of transition
of this country from an agrarian society through all the steps we went
through to becoming a modern, industrialized and shortly an automated
706: Richard Doud: I'm sure this thing could be carried to a limit
that would include just about everything in American life, so it would
709: Richard Doud: Industry and science and the arts.
715: Theodor Jung: And it would be quite a vast thing.

need, I think, is to all look in ourselves in a really graphic and
754: Richard Doud: Certainly the FSA experience would fit nicely in there.
757: Richard Doud: In something of that sort.
763: Theodor Jung: Well, that would be my comment about what the FSA experience

782: Richard Doud: Well, it's an exciting suggestion. I would like to see

791: Theodor Jung: I think we pretty well covered most of the things and I'm
really kind of surprised at how much I've been able to come up with. It
sort of brought back something of the enthusiasm and intellectual
ferment that was characteristic of the New Deal era.
809: Richard Doud: I'm not surprised you did. I don't know whether you are,

826: Theodor Jung: Very enjoyable and very happy to be able to have the
